seriesJson.title: Why is a writer?
seriesJson.description: Produced by the Iowa School of the Air, this series focuses on various works of literature from Shakespeare to Twain.

node.title: Irving's old New York
node.description: This program, "Irving's Old New York," focuses on Washington Irving.

subject.name: Irving, Washington, 1783-1859. History of New York

node.title: Jonson in jail
node.description: This program focuses on playwright Ben Jonson.

node.title: The hired pen
node.description: The Hired Pen, which deals with English history during King Charles II. The Hired Pen was John Dryden.

node.title: Behind the humorist
node.description: Behind the Humorist, about the story of Mark Twain's double role in life: as writer and on a personal level.

node.title: The writer who thinks
node.description: This program, "The Writer Who Thinks", focuses on Jonathan Swift.

node.title: The Jungle
node.description: The Jungle, by Upton Sinclair, about social and health reform in the meat industry.

node.title: The Adventurer
node.description: This program focuses on Joseph Conrad, who wrote of adventures at sea.

node.title: Utopia
node.description: This program focuses on Utopia, by Sir Thomas More. The book is a critique of conditions in England in the fifteenth century.

node.title: Gilbert and Sullivan
node.description: Gilbert and Sullivan, and the comedy operetta in 19th century England.

node.title: The writer for children
node.description: The Writer for Children, in this case, Robert Louis Stevenson, who was an adult yet was a still a child in the way he viewed the world.

node.title: Old Ironsides
node.description: Old Ironsides, written by Oliver Wendell Holmes, was a successful attempt to save the Revolutionary warship Constitution, which had been destined for scrap.

node.title: The grand sacrifice
node.description: This program explores the reasons behind John Milton's decision to defend his political beliefs, although the choice meant almost certain total blindness.

node.title: Walt Whitman, the free American
node.description: This program focuses on American poet Walt Whitman.

node.title: The literary cheat
node.description: This program, "The Literary Cheat," focuses on Thomas Chatterton, a brilliant young man who attempted to represent his forgeries as the work of a fifteenth-century priest. Chatterton died in 1770 at age 18.

node.title: The frail lady
node.description: This program focuses on American poet Emily Dickinson.

node.title: William Blake's vision
node.description: This program focuses on William Blake, who campaigned against conditions under which the poor children of England were reared in the 1790s.

node.title: The secret press
node.description: This program is about the Secret Press, which was operated by a man who called himself Martin Marprelate. He produced pamphlets satirizing England's Queen Elizabeth I in 1588 and 1589.

node.title: Shakespeare or not, that is the question
node.description: This program examines whether William Shakespeare actually wrote the plays which are generally credited to him.

node.title: Beggar's opera
node.description: This program features a dramatization of the debut of The Beggar's Opera, written by Englishman John Gay, in 1728.

node.title: Undecided
node.description: This program, "The Undecided," focuses on Edgar Allan Poe.

node.title: Critic of the king
node.description: This program focuses on English writer Leigh Hunt, also known as James Henry Leigh Hunt.

node.title: Mark Twain on the Mississippi
node.description: This program focuses on the formative years of Samuel L. Clemens.
